newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Institute sees tin demand up 41,000 T in 2000.
newsitem.headline: Institute sees tin demand up 41,000 T in 2000.

text.p: New uses for tin are expected to result in increased demand of 41,000 tonnes in 2000, compared with growth of 7,600 tonnes in 1996, said Rod Bedder, International Tin Research Institute managing director.

But about 50 percent of growth in 1996 due to new applications was offset by declining demand for traditional uses. In 1997, new demand is set to grow by 12,650 tonnes while traditional demand is expected to fall by 20 percent.
The biggest growth in demand in 2000 is expected to be for lead-free shot with some 10,000 tonnes of tin used to manufacture cartridges for hunting birds and wild animals.
Although more expensive than lead cartridges, they conform with increasingly strict environmental laws.
Lead-free solders, used by the electronics industry and in casting alloys, is expected to consume an extra 8,000 tonnes in 2000, against 1,500 tonnes in 1996 and potential growth of 30,000 tonnes.
Consumption of tin in fire-retardant chemicals is expected to rise by 7,000 tonnes in 2000, compared with 500 tonnes in 1996 and potential growth of 30,000 tonnes.
Other growth areas are seen in tin plate and batteries.
The British-based research institute was created by a group of tin producers in 1995 to develop new outlets for tin and increase world tin consumption by 20,000 to 30,000 tonnes annually.
